Key Arguments: The bill lacks a philosophical foundation and attempts to legislate truth, which is baseless in contemporary Australia.
The bill would stifle scientific and medical progress by potentially banning dissenting views that later prove to be true.
The bill undermines democratic principles by allowing unelected bureaucrats to control online expression.
The bill could enforce a single ideological narrative, destroying freedom of expression.
The bill violates international obligations, specifically Article 19 of the UN Declaration of Human Rights.
The bill would stifle public debate, which is essential for a healthy society.
The bill exempts government and professional news outlets, creating a double standard.
The bill mirrors authoritarian practices by restricting freedom of expression.
The bill's record-keeping requirements could lead to privacy invasions and a 'dissident blacklist'.
Notable Quotes: This bill lacks any philosophical foundation.
This bill would stifle scientific and medical progress and damage those living in its time.
This is not representative democracy. It is not government by the people for the people.
This bill would destroy freedom of expression.
This bill would destroy that freedom.
